> That's right.
>
> David Saff
>
>
> On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 2:25 PM, Raphael Parree <rparree@...<rparree%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
> > David,
> >
> > Just to make sure: do you mean that the AllMembersSupplier's addFields
> > method should filter fields those having a @DataPoint annotation and not
> > just all that are public and static?
> >
> > Raphael
> >
> > On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 7:46 PM, David Saff <david@...<david%40saff.net>>
> wrote:
> >
> >> Raphael,
> >>
> >> You're right. It's a bug. Only @DataPoint fields should be used.
> >> Can you log the bug? Thanks,
> >>
> >> David Saff
> >>
> >>
> >> On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 3:47 AM, Raphael Parree
> >> <rparree@... <rparree%40gmail.com><rparree%40gmail.com>>
> >> wrote:
> >> > Hi,
> >> >
> >> > Looking at the default data supplier for Theories (
> >> > org.junit.experimental.theories.internal.AllMembersSupplier) it seems
> to
> >> me
> >> > the @DataPoint annotation only has an effect on methods. If that is
> >> indeed
> >> > the case perhaps the annotation should be defined with Target
> >> > ElementType.METHOD?
> >> >
> >> > The reason is that the AllMembersSupplier's getValueSources uses the
> >> > addFields which includes all public static fields regardless of any
> >> > annotation (except for the plurar version DataPoints for arrays).
> >> Therefore
> >> > it does not matter whether you use the @DataPoint annotation on
> fields.
> >> > Perhaps the implementation of addFields should use it, in which case
> the
> >> > target of the @DataPoint annotation should include fields.
> >> >
> >> > Thanks,
> >> >
> >> > Raphael
